description.narrative:
The Gender transformative and Responsible Agribusiness Investment in South East Asia (GRAISEA) programme is a joint OGB/ONL regional programme in South East Asia financed by Embassy of Sweden Bangkok office for the period January 1, 2015 - March 31, 2018(3 years and 3 months inception period). It is a regional programme based on the recognition that financial viability and gender equitable/sustainable supply chains are not mutually exclusive, and that win-win-win propositions (community/environment wins, women and men small-scale producers win, and larger businesses win) are possible.
Building on Oxfams pilots in selected commodities (palm oil and aquaculture), this programme will utilise a multi-stakeholder approach, with Oxfam acting as a convenorto bring together the diverse stakeholders to achieve the following results:
Result 1. (Contribute to) ASEAN and its member states policies have a stronger role in promoting responsible practices in agribusiness, in agribusiness investment, in small-scale agriculture and social enterprises Result 2. Small-scale producers are effectively linked up in agro-commercial value chains and women are recognized in these as central economic actors Result 3. Leading corporate agribusinesses in South East Asiahave adopted corporate social responsibility policiesand plans that support responsible practices in the value chains for women and men small-scale producers Result 4. Financial Institutions and investors in agriculture invest responsibly by introducing /developing innovative financing solutions to assist overcoming specific investment requirements (investment risks) in smallholders and buyers of these smallholders.so
This programme has been designed to take full advantage of both Oxfams and partners experiences in the region, including working with ASEAN (primarily the ASEAN Ministerial meeting on Agriculture and Forestry and SME working group) to influence the regional operating environment, as well as Oxfam?s expertise in gender equality to strengthen the individual and collective capacities of women and men smallholders. The programme works with 5 regional partners (Change Fusion, CSR Asia, Institute of Social Entrepeneurship in Asia (ISEA), SEAFish for justice network, Shujog/Impact InvestmentExchange (IIX) as well as the Oxfam GROW regional campaign team, Oxfam experts in MultiStakeholder Initiatives especially Round Table on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) and Aquaculture Stewardship Council (ASC) and Oxfam offices and country partners in Indonesia,Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar, Philippines, and Thailand.
OGB regional office in Bangkok is lead. ONLwill be responsible for implementation as executing affiliate in Vietnam and Cambodia and provide technical (Private sector and gender) as well as overall support.
PARTNER ORGANISATION
OGB Regional Centre in Bangkok will be leading this programme and be responsible for its implementation. An interaffiliate agreement has been established between OGB and ONL re. roles and responsibilities of each. ONLwill be member of the Programme Steering Committee.
Contribution to ONL impact indicators
1 : 50% 11: 50%

participating-org.narrative: Development and Partnership in Action (DPA) is a non-political, non-religious, non- partisan, non-profit making Cambodian non-governmental organization devoted to furthering community development, partnership work with Cambodian NGOs and lobbying and advocacy. DPA is the successor of CIDSE Cambodia which was established in 1979 as part of the larger CIDSE CLV programme created by a consortiumof International NGOs from Europe, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. With a mission spanning more than 25 years,the milestones andachievements of CIDSE Cambodia are significant, not least of which is moving from meeting basic daily needs of beneficiaries to focusing on strategic long-term aims of building capacity and empowering partner organizations to assist in changing their target communities lives. CIDSE Cambodia began funding CNGOS in 1993 and formally established the Partnership Programme in 1994. Due to the evolving social climate and the strong capacity and commitment of its local staff, CIDSE Cambodia decided to localize and in 1996 began a transition process which enabled the organization to emerge as DPA in January 2006. DPA assumed responsibility for all work of CIDSE Cambodia from 1 January 2006, with an emphasis on community organizing (CO) and rights-based (RB) strategies.
